msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Former Prophets, the Book of Ruth, the Book of Esther, and some passages of the Book of Proverbs

ab.title: Ruth 2
ab.l: And Naomi had a friend of her husband’s, a mighty man of the army, of the family of Elimelech; and his name was Boaz.
And Ruth the Moabitess said to Naomi, ‘Let me go now to the field, and glean ears of grain after him in whose sight I shall find grace.’ And she said to her, ‘Go, my daughter.’
And she went, and came, and gleaned in the field after the reapers: and she happened to come to a part of the field that was of Boaz who was of the family of Elimelech.
And, behold, Boaz came from Bethlehem, and said to the reapers, ‘The Lord be with you.’ And they answered him, ‘The Lord bless you.’
Then said Boaz to his servant standing over the reapers, ‘Whose young woman is this?’
And answered the servant that was set over the reapers and said, ‘It is the Moabite woman that came back with Naomi out of the plain of Moab.
And she said, “Let me glean now and gather among the sheaves after the reapers”. And she came and has continued from early morning until now, she sat a little in the house.’
And Boaz said to Ruth, ‘Behold, listen, my daughter, do not go to glean in another field or even leave this one, but keep close thus to my maid-servants.

Let your eyes be on the field that they are reaping, and go after them. Behold, I have instructed the servants not to touch you. And when you are thirsty, go to the vessels and drink of that which the servants would say.’
Then she fell on her face, and bowed to the ground, and said to him, ‘Why have I found grace in your eyes, that you should take knowledge of me, since I am a foreigner?’

And Boaz answered her, and said to her ‘It has fully been told to me,
all that you have done to your mother-in-law since the death of your husband: and how you have left your father and your mother, and the land of your birth and came to a people that you did not know the day before.
May the Lord pay your reward for what you have done, and may a full reward be given you by the Lord, the God of Israel, under whose providence you have come to take refuge!’
Then she said, ‘I found favour in the eyes of my lord; for you have comforted me, and you have spoken to the hearts of your handmaids, though I am not one of your servants.
And Boaz said to her at mealtime, ‘Come closer, and eat of the bread, and dip your morsel in the vinegar.’ And she sat beside the reapers: and he passed to her roasted grain , and she ate, and left.
And she rose to glean, and Boaz instructed his servants, saying, ‘Let her gather even among the sheaves, and do not put her to shame.
And also leave some from the sheaves for her and leave it for her to gather, and do not rebuke her.’

And she gleaned in the field until evening, and she beat out what she had gleaned, and it was about a kebič
of barley.
And she took it up and went into the city, and her mother-in-law saw what she had gleaned and she also brought out and gave to her what she had reserved after she was satisfied.

And her mother-in-law said to her, ‘Where did you glean today? And where did you work? May the man who took notice of you be blessed.’ So she told her mother-in-law whom she had gathered with and said, ‘The man’s name with whom I gathered today is Boaz.’

And Naomi said to her daughter-in-law, ‘May he be blessed by the Lord, who has not left off his kindness to the living or the dead!’ and Naomi said to her, ‘A close relative of ours is the man, one of our redeemers.’

And Ruth the Moabite said, ‘Besides, he
also said to me, “You shall keep close by the servants of mine until they have completed all my harvest.”’
And Naomi said to Ruth, her daughter-in-law, ‘It is good, my daughter, that you go out with his maid-servants, let them not meet you in another field.’
And she kept close to the maid-servants of Boaz, gleaning until the end of the barley harvest and wheat harvest; and she dwelt with her mother-in-law.

app.note: Reconstructed based on ADub.III.73 and Eup.

EKar. Ütkän ašlyq. In ADub.III.73: pražma. Its meaning is reconstructed based on the Hebrew original, cf. קָלִי ‘roasted grain’ or ‘parched corn’ (Ruth 2:14), see also Klein (1987: 579). The meaning of the Slavonic etymon of the word used in ADub.III.73, i.e. ESlav. пряжити is ‘to roast’, cf. пряжити in the 17th–18th-century Russian (SRJa 21: 25).
A measurement unit, cf. Tksh. dial. kebiç ‘an amount of wheat given to the miller as an equivalent for his work’ (DerS 8: 2714).
